results.description:
You are cordially invited to our first Ruby Meetup...
We will be discussing several items - the group direction, projects, interests, work- and non-work related code... and most importantly - 

What do you want?

My primary goal in starting this meetup was finding the Chicago Ruby community and providing a center for planning and activity. I was happy to find that Chirb is already going strong. I think, however, that there is a room to do more.

I would like this meetup to focus on working together, sharing knowledge, and working on projects. How does one write good code? How does one get a project going and keep it healthy?

I want to build a network of people who want to get things done - to motivate and be motivated in turn by talking and above all doing work with others.

Come out to the first meeting - let's see what we can do.

We will meet at: Forest Park Library, November 5 (Sunday), 3 pm. Library is at the corner of DesPlaines and Jackson, about 1 block from the Forest Park Blue Line station (north on DesPlaines Rd.)
results.name: First Ruby Meetup Scheduled

results.description:
Many of you pointed out - I must not have a mother. I do. I am just a horrible human being and didn't realize May 13 is Mothers' Day.

As such, I am postponing the meetup another week.

My apologies to you and your mothers... and mine.

Steve R.

===================================================

ARGH! My apologies - your organizer has to leave town Sunday for work (I'm a consultant). I'm moving the Meetup back a week to Sunday, May 13.

My apologies.

===================================================

The May meetup is set.

Pick the programming 'itch' you've been meaning to 'scratch' to make your development / job / life better and bring it down and pitch it. 

The goal - project 'teams'. We will also set a date for the subsequent meetup to share progress. 

If you can't recruit helpers, you can do a project on your own - of whatever level of complexity you like.

If you have no ideas, join a group and help someone else - the experience will do you good!

This meetup will be discussion format, but future meetups will include demonstrations of projects in progress.

Please note, all projects are assumed to be 'public' unless you state otherwise, and you need to tell project participants up front. Meetings are public, and all presentations given at meetings are also public, so if you want something kept private, don't present it.

The fee is optional, but I am out of pocket for all meetups - any contribution is welcome.
results.name: May Ruby Meetup!

results.description:
Continuing out development of the 'Lease' project, as well as fielding other projects, we will meet at the same place as we have previously.

I'll send out an itinerary closer to the date - please send suggestions. I think putting together a timeline and milestones for the lease project would be the minimum we should work toward.

Other projects and suggestions are, as always, welcome.

See you there!

SR
results.name: July Ruby Meetup scheduled!

results.description:
Welcome Ruby Enthusiasts!

This will be our first meeting in the new format. Our goal is to cover topics at multiple levels: beginner, intermediate, and advanced. If we make it interesting for everybody, we'll all get a chance to both learn and contribute. Here's the agenda for our August 18, 2007 meeting:

Beginner/Newbie Topic (30 minutes)
[BobbyJacob] Review one chapter or topic from the "Agile" book

Intermediate Topics (30 minutes)
[Wil Chung] "How do you find the answer to X in gems? (Learning how to fish...)
[Wil Chung] "How do I learn more about a particular API?"

Advanced Topic (normally 30 minutes)
Postponed at this meeting in favor of Problem Solving (below)

Problem Solving or Project Discussion (30 minutes)
[Steve Rummel or Bobby Jacob] Lease Project
[Mingde Hong (Victor)] Captchas

Conference Recap (15 minutes)
[Ray Hightower] RailsConf 2007 Recap

Creation of Next Meeting Agenda (15 minutes)
[All Participants] Input from current participants determines agenda for next meeting

Note: The $3.00 meeting fee covers room rental.
results.name: Multi-Level Ruby

results.description:
Three levels in one meeting: Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced

* Beginner: Agile Rails (30 minutes)

* Intermediate: Overview of RadiantCMS (30 minutes)

* Advanced: When All Else Fails, Go Rails Spelunking (30 minutes)

* Kick-Off for the RadiantCMS extensions project. (15 minutes)

* Wrap Up and Discussion of Next Agenda (15 minutes)
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Multi-Level Ruby

results.description:
This month at ChicagoRuby.org... Something different while still covering multiple levels of expertise:

    * Hobo - an extension that increases the speed of Rails development even further. Presented by Victor Hong.

    * When Rails Fails - What happens when Rails fails, and what can we do about it?

If you have ideas or opinions on either of these topics, come by and be heard!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Multi-Level Ruby

results.description:
* Overview of the "Agile" Book presented by by Bobby Jacob. If you're new to Rails, you'll appreciate this installment of the ongoing series.

* Google Maps and Rails Apps presented by Michael Gurley. The presenter will show how he has integrated Google Maps into a live Rails-driven application.

* Unstructured Hackfest - A great chance to experiment with what we learn that day. Bring your Rails-equipped laptop!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Agile, Google, & Hackfest

results.description:
* Domain Specific Languages: DSLs make it easy to write powerful systems. Wil Chung will show you how.

* Agile Web Development With Rails: Each installment grows more powerful, especially during the interactive Q & A led by Bobby Jacob.

* GigaFloat: Victor Hong shows the practical aspects of developing & deploying a Rails-based project, [url=http://GigaFloat.com]GigaFloat.com[/url].
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org - Agile, GigaFloat, and DSLs

results.description:
The next [url=http://chicagoruby.org]ChicagoRuby.org[/url] meeting will be held Sat, Jan 19, 2008 at 3pm. Our agenda:

* Rails 2.0 Sexy Migrations by Matt Polito (20 min)
* Agile by Bobby Jacob (45 min)
* Flex by Josh Starcher (30 min)
* Home Brew App Deployment by Mike Wagner (15 min)

As always, something for every level of Ruby interest. See you there!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Flex, Rails 2.0, and More

results.description:
[url=http://www.metromix.com]Metromix[/url] was originally part of [url=http://www.tribuneinteractive.com/]Tribune Interactive[/url]. The app has been completely re-designed using Ruby on Rails, and it is now being deployed to multiple cities across the USA.

[url=http://www.linkedin.com/profile?viewProfile=&key=8592107]Evan Petrie[/url], Senior Developer at Metromix, will present the technology behind the app and discuss the challenges & rewards of bringing [url=http://rubyonrails.org/]Ruby on Rails[/url] into a [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J2ee]J2EE[/url] organization. Tim Wise (Director of Technology at Metromix) will also be on hand to answer questions.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Metromix on Rails

results.description:
[url=http://www.morphexchange.com/]Morph eXchange[/url] will host the 3/15/2008 meeting of ChicagoRuby.org. After that, ChicagoRuby.org co-organizer Will Chung will lead us through the development & deployment of one of his Rails apps: [url=http://mobtropolis.com]Mobtropolis[/url]. 

If you're a Rails developer and/or entrepreneur,  you may prefer to focus on the [i]meat[/i] of your app and let someone else handle load balancing, monitoring, backups, and other day-to-day tasks. Lincoln Murphy from Morph eXchange will answer questions such as:

[list]
[*]If demand for my Rails app goes through the roof, how can I manage the increased volume?
[*]What is an elastic environment, and why do I care?
[*]How can I leverage [url=http://www.amazon.com/gp/browse.html?node=201590011]Amazon EC2[/url] and [url=http://www.amazon.com/gp/browse.html?node=16427261]S3[/url] in my app?
[*]What's the best way to deploy updated versions of my app?
[/list]

Stick around and chat with Lincoln about other issues that concern you. Be sure to reserve your spot! See you in March!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Morph eXchange in March

results.description:
Our April meeting will start off with [url=http://almosteffortless.com/eldorado/ ]El Dorado[/url] by [url=http://www.workingwithrails.com/person/8170-trevor-turk]Trevor Turk[/url]. El Dorado is a community web app written in Rails. Trevor will share stories from the trenches including lessons learned and why he chose [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git_%28software%29]Git[/url] over [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subversion_%28software%29]Subversion[/url].

If you're launching a Rails app, [url=http://ruby.meetup.com/77/members/6789412/]Yan Pritzker[/url] from [url=http://www.cohesiveft.com/ ]CohesiveFT[/url] will tell you where to put it. Yan will give a brief overview of Elastic Server On-Demand (ESOD), a Rails-based web application that is used to create virtualized servers from a catalog of application components. A demo will be given of how to create a ready-to-go Rails stack and run your application on it without concern about remembering what you did to make the environment work.

For an earlier discussion of El Dorado, visit the [url=http://groups.google.com/group/chicagoruby/browse_thread/thread/afab8dda54bbc4bc]ChicagoRuby.org Google Group[/url]. See you in April!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: El Dorado and ESOD

results.description:
[url=http://blog.andyamiri.com/]Andy Amiri[/url] will cover some simple ways to take an existing version 1.0-type app and bring it up to speed with [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AJAX]AJAX[/url].

NOTE: This meeting will NOT be held in our normal Elmhurst location. Please sign in to get the address for the May 2008 ChicagoRuby.org meeting.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: AJAX, Money, & Rice

results.description:
[url=http://railsconf.com]RailsConf 2008[/url] in Portland, OR, USA
O'Reilly offers a discount to [url=http://chicagoruby.org/our-sponsors]ChicagoRuby.org members[/url].
results.name: Rails Conf 2008 - Portland, OR

results.description:
[url=http://railsconf.com]RailsConf 2008[/url] in Portland, OR, USA
O'Reilly offers a discount to [url=http://chicagoruby.org/our-sponsors]ChicagoRuby.org members[/url].
results.name: Rails Conf 2008 - Portland, OR

results.description:
[url=http://railsconf.com]RailsConf 2008[/url] in Portland, OR, USA
O'Reilly offers a discount to [url=http://chicagoruby.org/our-sponsors]ChicagoRuby.org members[/url].
results.name: Rails Conf 2008 - Portland, OR

results.description:
[url=http://railsconf.com]RailsConf 2008[/url] in Portland, OR, USA
O'Reilly offers a discount to [url=http://chicagoruby.org/our-sponsors]ChicagoRuby.org members[/url].
results.name: Rails Conf 2008 - Portland, OR

results.description:
Over 1,800 developers from around the world gathered in Portland, OR for [url=http://railsconf.com]RailsConf2008[/url]. ChicagoRuby.org was well-represented!

Members who attended RailsConf2008 will share conference highlights with the group. Topics to be overviewed include:
[list]
[*]Behavior Driven Development (BDD) - What's the deal with stories?
[*]Design Patterns - Don't re-invent the wheel.
[*]Entrepreneurs on Rails - Ideas, goals, and branding.
[/list]
Beginners will enjoy the overview nature of the meeting, while experienced Rubyists will enjoy bouncing ideas off of other experienced people in the group. See you there!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: RailsConf Recap

results.description:
Kris Hicks will present Automator, a tool used to automate the main web application at First American Title. In building this internal app, Kris merged his knowledge of company business logic with technology (Ruby, Merb, and Watir). Anyone who wants to learn more about packaging and distributing Ruby, browser automation with Watir, or building with Merb will find this talk interesting.

The July meeting will be held at IIT/Chicago. After the meeting we'll walk over to the site of [url=http://windycityrails.org/]WindyCityRails[/url] to answer questions and finalize logistics for the event. See you there!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Ruby in the Trenches

results.description:
[list][*][url=http://blog.reborg.net/]Renzo Borgatti[/url] of [url=http://obtiva.com]Obtiva[/url] will present Ruby Driven Java Development.
[*][url=http://pracstrat.com/]Nate Kirby[/url] of [url=http://pracstrat.com/]Practical Strategies[/url] will share his real-world experience with testing.
[/list]


[b]Ruby Driven Java Development[/b]
[url=http://blog.reborg.net/]Renzo Borgatti[/url] of [url=http://obtiva.com]Obtiva[/url] will show working examples of Ruby driven Java development starting from a pure text user story with scenarios, creating rSpec specifications, down to the Java code that makes those scenarios to pass. You can preview part of the content in this [url=http://www.vimeo.com/1283592]screencast[/url].

[b]Testing Experiences and Best Practices[/b]
[url=http://pracstrat.com/]Nate Kirby[/url] of [url=http://pracstrat.com/]Practical Strategies[/url] will share his real-world experience with testing including best practices and ways to avoid common pitfalls. Nate will cover RSpec and StoryRunner.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Testing - Multiple Approaches

results.description: WindyCityRails is a gathering for all who are passionate about Ruby on Rails. The conference is sold out and tickets will NOT be sold at the door. You might think of WindyCityRails as our September meeting in amplified form! Visit http://WindyCityRails.org for details and registration.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org Presents WindyCityRails (SOLD OUT)

results.description:
In October, [url=http://www.workingwithrails.com/person/7465-matt-polito]Matt Polito[/url] of [url=http://www.reactioncontrol.com/]reactionCONTROL[/url] will show how to integrate Google Apps with your Rails applications. Matt will also offer tips & tricks for beginning & intermediate Rails developers. He encourages the audience to throw out more tips unknown to him so that everyone can learn together. Come with your thinking caps on!

And... we will recover from all of the work required for WindyCityRails :-)
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Google Apps With Rails

results.description:
RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL
http://rubyconf.org/
results.name: RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL

results.description:
RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL
http://rubyconf.org/
results.name: RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL

results.description:
RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL
http://rubyconf.org/
results.name: RubyConf 2008 in Orlando, FL

results.description: Jeff Cohen, co-author of [url=http://oreilly.com]Rails for .Net Developers[/url], will give a brief overview of REST. The presentation will be geared for those new to REST, regardless of how long you've been using Rails. We assume you can at least create a simple Rails app, but not much more than that. Come ready with questions for Jeff!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: REST in November

results.description: This meeting will be all about code. Bring your laptop and your toughest Ruby on Rails problem and we'll attack the problem as a group. The meeting will start with 5-minute lightning talks followed by an intense collaboration session. If we don't solve the problem, we'll at least make a dent in it!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Lightning Talks & Collaboration

results.description:
[url=http://www.pathf.com/blogs/author/noel-rappin/]Noel Rappin[/url] will present [i]Getting Started With Rails Testing[/i]. Noel is Vice-President of Rails Development for [url=http://www.pathf.com]Pathfinder Development[/url]. He is the author of [url=http://www.amazon.com/Professional-Ruby-Rails-Programmer/dp/047022388X/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1231867060&sr=8-1]Professional Ruby on Rails[/url] and the forthcoming self-published [i]Rails Test Prescriptions: Keeping Your Applications Healthy[/i], available at [url=http://www.railsprescriptions.com]RailsPrescriptions.com[/url].

We will still feature lightning talks & collaboration toward the end of the meeting. Send your ideas for lightning talks to organizers{at}chicagoruby{dot}org. Visit http://chicagoruby.org for more details.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Getting Started With Rails Testing

results.description:
In a short time frame Rails is moving from version 2.2, to 2.3, to (with the Merb merge) 3.0. In that same period Ruby will grow from version 1.8.7 to 1.9.1. How do you keep up? How do you run multiple versions of Ruby and Rails on the same machine?

Well discuss one multi-version method at our Feb 21, 2009 meeting. And if you have a few tips & tricks of your own, come prepared to share!
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Multi-Level Ruby

results.description:
[b]Migrating a Legacy App to Rails[/b]
At our Jan2009 meeting, Jeremy Peterson presented on a script to convert a special database data (non-normalized table) application over to Rails. This project is wrapping up and a final update on this project will be discussed.  He'll discuss how we added files and images from the PHP application and making handling exceptions for the data.

[b]Creating Form Builders Using JQuery[/b]
Peter Sidebotham will build upon the TabularFormBuilder example in [url=http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780977616602/index.html]Rails Recipes[/url] by Chad Fowler. Peter's extension includes a tabular form builder that adds some fields and options beyond what's in the rails recipe example. It also includes a second form builder that provides edit in place functionality using jquery, to switch from displaying labels to form elements. Additionally, the tabular form builder can make a nested call to the edit in place builder, providing combined functionality.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Legacy Migrations & Forms

results.description:
Practice makes perfect. Just as athletes and musicians must regularly take the time to focus on perfecting their craft, so must we. And what better way to practice, than hanging out with a group of like-minded Rubyists? A [url=http://codingdojo.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?WhatIsCodingDojo]Coding Dojo[/url] is designed to do just that. 

[url=http://davegiunta.com/]Dave Giunta[/url] will take us through a [url=http://codingdojo.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?RandoriKata]RandoriKata[/url] wherein we will each take turns pair-programming a solution to a given problem, using baby steps and [url=http://codingdojo.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?TestDrivenDevelopment]Test Driven Development[/url] with [url=http://rspec.info/]RSpec[/url] and [url=http://cukes.info/]Cucumber[/url]. If you want to come a little extra prepared, check out the [url=http://www.butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.TheBowlingGameKata]Bowling Kata[/url] ahead of time. All skill levels are encouraged to join us, even if you've never done pair programming, Test Driven Development, RSpec or Cucumber.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Coding Dojo

results.description: RailsConf 2009 - Hilton Las Vegas
results.name: RailsConf - Hilton Las Vegas

results.description: RailsConf 2009 - Hilton Las Vegas
results.name: RailsConf - Hilton Las Vegas

results.description: RailsConf 2009 - Hilton Las Vegas
results.name: RailsConf - Hilton Las Vegas

results.description: RailsConf 2009 - Hilton Las Vegas
results.name: RailsConf - Hilton Las Vegas

results.description:
Do you need to create a simple web application?  Do you think a big web framework may actually be too much for what you need?  We all love Rails, yet at times it's just too much power for the task at hand.  [url=http://matt.puchlerz.com/]Matt Puchlerz[/url] will introduce [url=http://www.sinatrarb.com/]Sinatra[/url], a light-weight DSL used to quickly and easily create web applications.  He will guide us through the creation of a simple web app, utilizing the Bowling::Game class we began creating during last month's coding dojo.  Along the way, we'll see a little more [url=http://cukes.info]Cucumber[/url] and/or [url=http://rspec.info/]RSpec[/url], and maybe even some [url=http://datamapper.org]DataMapper[/url].

After Matt's presentation, we will have an open discussion regarding the recent [url=http://en.oreilly.com/rails2009/]RailsConf 2009[/url] in Las Vegas.  Whether or not you were able to attend, come to discuss what you learned or find out what you missed.  Find out what's in store for Rails 3 or discuss the tips for running a successful web startup.  This section of the meeting will be more of an open format.  If you have some good notes from the conference, please come share them with the community.
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Sinatra and RailsConf Recap

results.description:
Join us after work in downtown Chicago. Noel Rappin, author of Rails Test Prescriptions (http://railsrx.com) will be our guest speaker. Meet others in the downtown Chicago Rails community for learning & networking.

If you can't make it to the meeting, try attending virtually!  This is our first attempt at this, so we ask for your patience.  We will be trying Citrix's GoToMeeting service, which allows for 15 attendees.  At this point we don't have an RSVP service, so whoever logs in first will get the preference.  If you have a question, send in a chat message during the meeting and we will unmute you so you can ask the question through your microphone.  Here's the info:

1.  Go to https://www2.gotomeeting.com/join/185230075

2.  Use your microphone and speakers (VoIP) - a headset is recommended. Or, call in using your telephone.

Dial 712-338-7101
Access Code: 185-230-075
Audio PIN: Shown after joining the meeting

Meeting ID: 185-230-075
results.name: ChicagoRuby.org: Rails Test Prescriptions

results.description:
Our July 18 meeting will be a bold step for ChicagoRuby. Our presenter, [url=http://www.rubyfocus.biz/]Wolfram Arnold[/url], is a Rails developer and agile consultant located in San Francisco. We will set up a remote connection with Wolf so that he can present at our meeting. If you are poor with model-based caching, stop by our meeting to learn more about [url=http://agilewebdevelopment.com/plugins/cache_money]Cache Money[/url], which is a write-through and read-through caching library for ActiveRecord.

During the second half of the meeting, Constantin Gavrilescu will give a presentation about his startup, TruckerZoom. Constantin will speak from experience to talk about some of the lessons learned. The topics will include multi-tenant applications, security with role-based authentication, access control using named scopes, working and staying motivated, and getting specifications from the client.

Wolfram Arnold, Ph.D. is a seasoned software professional with 17 years of experience, co-founder of 3 companies, and has been working on consumer web applications in Ruby-on-Rails since 2006.

Constantin Gavrilescu has been working professionally with Ruby on Rails for 2.5 years.  He first heard about it in a Slashdot comment 3 years ago.  When he's not programming in Ruby, he develops with C in Linux and does some Linux system administration.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Cache Money and TruckerZoom

results.description:
Join us for our first downtown meeting since the [url=http://chicagoruby.org/a-tale-of-two-groups]merge with Chirb[/url]. Pizza & mingling begin at 6pm. Presentations start at 6:30pm. 

Two presentations: 
* Drew Jemilo - "Agile, Scrum, Extreme Programming, and Lean: What Does It Mean to Ruby?"

* Jake Scruggs - "When You Should Test Less" -  Is it possible to test too much? Balance is key!

[b]Agile, Scrum, Extreme Programming, and Lean: What Does It Mean to Ruby?[/b] Ruby helps you develop software quickly and adapt to fast-changing market conditions.  But can your methodology accelerate your adaptability and development speed? Yes, and [url=http://fastfrontier.com]Drew Jemilo[/url] will show you how.

[b]When You Should Test Less[/b] [url=http://jakescruggs.blogspot.com/]Jake Scruggs[/url] has been on teams with way too little and (heresy) way too much testing. There have been lots of talks about how you should test more, but Jake is going to dare to talk about when you should test less. Too much testing can lead to backlash, gridlock, morale problems, and poor velocity. Of course lack of testing can lead to bad design, gridlock, morale problems, and poor velocity. Balance is the way to go.

[b]WindyCityRails Early Registration Ends August 1st[/b] Register for WindyCityRails by August 1, 2009 and save $50.00. The schedule has something for Rubyists of all levels, beginner through advanced. All participants will enjoy the Obtiva Coding Dojo - a powerful coding experience that lasts all day! Drop by http://windycityrails.org for more info and to register. See you at the conference!
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown - Agile & Ruby. Testing Less.

results.description:
[b]Coding Dojo: Part Deux  Practice Harder![/b]  Deliberate practice over a long period of time is at the heart of attaining expertise. At this, our second coding dojo, well be using RSpec, Cucumber and pair programming in concert to work through the Bowling Kata. Like last time, any skill level is welcome, though this time we plan to jump right into coding with very minimal setup.

For a head start, look for sites that discuss [url=http://codingdojo.org/]coding dojos[/url] and the [url=http://butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.TheBowlingGameKata]Bowling Kata[/url].

[b]WindyCityRails[/b]
If you enjoy ChicagoRuby, consider [url=http://windycityrails.org]WindyCityRails[/url], a full-day conference with strong presenters & a big challenge: the Obtiva Coding Dojo. Visit http://windycityrails.org for details.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst Coding Dojo

results.description: Software Craftsmanship North America is all about mastering the craft of software development. Visit http://scna.softwarecraftsmanship.org/ for details.
results.name: Software Craftsmanship North America

results.description:
There are many testing frameworks. Which one is best for a particular purpose or application? What criteria should influence your decision?

Find answers in this presentation. Tim Camper, Greg Warren, & Dima Kovalenko of [url=http://thoughtworks.com]ThoughtWorks[/url] will discuss the tools they used as they completed an app for a large US-based airline. Hands-on exercises are part of the meeting, so be prepared to write code!

[b]Please use your real name when you RSVP[/b] for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then [url=http://www.cuberick.com/2008/12/history-of-security-at-aon-center.html]Aon security[/url] will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.

[b]WindyCityRails: Sat, Sep 12, 2009[/b]
If you enjoy ChicagoRuby, consider [url=http://windycityrails.org]WindyCityRails[/url], a full-day conference with strong presenters & an all-day coding dojo. Visit http://windycityrails.org for details.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Functional Testing in Ruby With Hpricot, JavaScript, & Selenium

results.description: WindyCityRails is an annual conference for all who are passionate about Ruby on Rails. Visit http://WindyCityRails.org for details.
results.name: WindyCityRails

results.description:
John W. Long created Radiant, a Rails-based CMS, here in Chicago. Sean Cribbs is the current lead developer for Radiant. Long and Cribbs will join us via videoconference for an in depth discussion of Radiant.

Radiant is a no-fluff content management system built with Ruby on Rails.  Radiant makes it easy to get a new site up and running, but also makes it easy for developers to customize the experience for their users.  We'll discuss Radiant's core features, demonstrate setting up a basic site with Radiant, and discuss how it can be customized through the powerful extension system.

[b]Please use your real name when you RSVP[/b] for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then [url=http://www.cuberick.com/2008/12/history-of-security-at-aon-center.html]Aon security[/url] will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown - RadiantCMS with Sean Cribbs and John W. Long

results.description: An examination of four major cloud platforms (Google, Amazon, Sales Force & Microsoft) led by Tech in the Middle and SWI Consultants. Details are available at http://www.dayofcloud.com and http://www.swiconsultants.com.
results.name: Day of Cloud

results.description:
"We accept pair piloting and pair policing. Why is pair programming controversial?" - Tweeted by @patmaddox at #alohaonrails

Ginny Hendry (http://www.ghendry.net/) will take us through a pair programming exercise that is similar to a coding dojo except multiple people will pair at multiple workstations simultaneously. Come on out and try it even if you've never paired before. This is a great opportunity to learn!
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst  - Multiple Pairing Stations

results.description: A half-day traveling road show produced by EngineYard. Visit http://www.railsroadshow.com for details.
results.name: RailsRoadShow

results.description: GeneXus is a robust IDE for Ruby, plus other languages. The GeneXus free 2-day Users Conference, Nov 2-3, 2009, with a dinner Monday night, is open to ChicagoRuby members. All members are invited. More info: www.genexus.com/usa/event.
results.name: GeneXus Users' Conference

results.description: GeneXus is a robust IDE for Ruby, plus other languages. The GeneXus free 2-day Users Conference, Nov 2-3, 2009, with a dinner Monday night, is open to ChicagoRuby members. All members are invited. More info: www.genexus.com/usa/event.
results.name: GeneXus Users' Conference

results.description:
This meeting will focus on hands-on pair programming. Ginny Hendry led a great random pairing session in Elmhurst, so she's bringing her act downtown! People of every Ruby level are welcome to come and participate. Please come prepared with the following: a laptop with Ruby (http://ruby-lang.org) and RSpec (http://rspec.info) installed, a basic working knowledge of the Ruby language, a general knowledge of Conway's Game of Life (see Wikipedia).

Even if you've never programmed in Ruby, you're welcome to come and observe. You'll still have fun!

[b]Please use your real name when you RSVP[/b] for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then [url=http://www.cuberick.com/2008/12/history-of-security-at-aon-center.html]Aon security[/url] will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown - Random Pair Programming

results.description: Have you ever wanted to create your own Ruby on Rails plugin? Gabe Saravia has gone through the process and he will share his experiences with our group.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Elmhurst - Make Your Own Plugin 101

results.description:
Gary Levitt (of [url=http://madmimi.com]Mad Mimi[/url]) contacted Dave Hoover (of [url=http://obtiva.com]Obtiva[/url]) in early 2007 about building an email marketing web site in Ruby on Rails.  In subsequent months and years, Gary and Dave collaborated almost daily in order to improve, scale, fix, and market Mad Mimi into one of the leading email marketing sites on the web.  

Dave will share his biggest lessons from this project.  Most of the lessons are not technical, though Ruby and Rails certainly facilitated them.

[b]About Dave Hoover[/b]
Dave authored the book [url=http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780596518387/]Apprenticeship Patterns: Guidance for the Aspiring Software Craftsman[/url] for O'Reilly, instigated the [url=http://scna.softwarecraftsmanship.com/]Software Craftsmanship North America[/url] conference, and is the Chief Craftsman at Obtiva.  Dave learned Ruby in 2002 and has been using it full-time since 2006.  Dave lives in Wheaton with his wife and three children. In his spare time, Dave competes in endurance sports.

[b]Please use your real name when you RSVP[/b] for downtown ChicagoRuby meetings. Reason: We are required to give a list of all attendees to the security desk prior to the meeting. If the name on your ID doesn't the match the name on the RSVP list, then [url=http://www.cuberick.com/2008/12/history-of-security-at-aon-center.html]Aon security[/url] will not let you in the building. Sorry for the inconvenience, but those are the rules of the Aon Building.
results.name: ChicagoRuby: Downtown - Growing Mad Mimi: Sharing Disruptive Techniques
